text:
The pt is a 76 y/o F with multiple medical problems who presented to an
   outside hospital in early [**Month (only) 2965**] with increasing abdominal girth for
   5-days, followed by increasing right-upper quadrant pain. No previous
   history of ascities. Abdominal CT scan demonstrated massive asictes and
   bilateral pleural effusions. Further workup per report revealed normal
   TTE and nl abd US. Ultrasound guided biopsy did not show cirrhosis,
   fatty infiltration, or iron deposition. Diagnostic paracentesis
   negative for SBP, with serum-ascites albumin gradient of 1.1 suggestive
   of portal hypertension. She also underwent large volume (unclear
   amount) therapeutic paracentesis per discharge summary, but had
   reaccumulation of fluid. She was started on diuretics for her ascites,
   but noted to develop acute renal failure necessitating nephrology
   consult. Diuretic dose was reduced given concern for pre-renal azotemia
   secondary to poor PO intake and diuretics. During her hospital course,
   she had been afebrile, although appeared to have a leukocytosis to 15.3
   with 22% bands on CBC differential on the day of discharge. INR was
   also noted to be supratherapeutic at 7.3 and her warfarin was held. She
   was also reported to have foul-smelling urine and dysuria and was
   started on levofloxacin on the day of discharge. She was transferred to
   [**Hospital1 1**] for further evaluation and management of the above issues.
   .
   On arrival to [**Hospital1 1**] the patient, was empirically started on ceftriaxone
   and cipro for empiric SBP treatment as HCP unable to be contact[**Name (NI) **] to
   obtain consent for paracentesis. ARF worsened to Cr of 4.1, renal
   consult felt most c/w ATN. She was given a volume trial with albumin
   and a total of 3L NS today. This evening the patient developed atrial
   fibrillation with rate to 150s with acute change in MS. [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]
   negative. BP stable in 130s. Initally with mild resp distress with sat
   94% on RA but uncomfortable appearing. Pt began to complain of dyspnea
   and was placed on FM and given neb and 20IV lasix with 50cc urine
   output over 1hr. SL ntg. Sating 100% on 4L. Given 5mg IV lopressor for
   HR 130s followed by additional 5mg IV. CXR with volume overload. Given
   40mg IV lasix with minimal urine output. Pt now transferred to MICU for
   resp distress and oliguria. Per nightfloat upon discussion with HCP
   this evening, code status changed from DNR/DNI at OSH to Full Code now.
   .
   On arrival to MICU, the patient was resting more comfortably with
   decreased work of breathing, sating 95% on 2L. Alert but not oriented.
   CODE: At OSH pt was made DNR DNI: Attorney and Healthcare proxy [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Name (NI) 3581**]. Resident spoke directly with Ms. [**Name13 (STitle) 3581**] today, who expressed
   surprise that patient was DNR DNI at OSH. Ms. [**Name13 (STitle) 3581**] noted, however,
   that she was lucid enough at the OSH to have been able to communicate
   her true intentions and wishes. Given that OSH documentation indicates
   patient has been DNR DNI (recorded in the records presented on transfer
   and written on the pt's OSH wrist band),  conclusion of conversation
   was that patient would remain DNR DNI on evening of admission, and that
   the HCP would need come-in to the hospital to re-assess. After
   discussion following resp distress this pm code status was reversed to
   Full Code
   .
   # DISPO: Pending above evaluation.
   .
   Renal failure, acute (Acute renal failure, ARF)
   Assessment:
   pt with foley cath arrived to unit with 60cc clear yellow urine. Pt in
   afib with hr in the 90
s. temp 97.9 po, bp 100 to 106, lung sounds with
   crackles all the way up pt
s lung fields.
   Action:
   pt treated on [**Hospital Ward Name **] 10 with 3l fluid with minimal response then treated
   with lasix with minimal response. Tonight here in the unit pt given
   120mg iv lasix and then 500mg chlorothiazide.
   Response:
   u/o picking up slightly, lung sounds cont to have crackles.
   Plan:
   monitor u/o, urine electrolytes
   Altered mental status (not Delirium)
   Assessment:
   pt with increasing confusion on the floor, on arrival pt with eyes open
   but unresponsive to voice. Pt moving all extremeties and moaning but
   unable to state why.
   Action:
   pt received Lactulose enema. Pt without ngt since she pulled 2 of them
   out on [**Hospital Ward Name **] 10. Head ct done before arriving to micu and was neg for
   head bleed.
   Response:
   pt able to hold enema for some time and after about an hour pt was
   calling out and asking for a blanket because she was cold. Pt was able
   to state her name and new that she was in the hospital.
   Plan:
   cont with Lactulose enema/ Lactulose po if able to take.
   Ascites
   Assessment:
   pt with very large distended and firm abd. Pt appears to have some diff
   breathing and taking shallow breaths d/t abd pressing up on her
   diaphragm. Pt initially with face mask on and maintaining o2 sat
s of
   100%. Pt took mask off and cont to maintain o2 sat
s in the high 90
   Action:
   keep hob elev to facilitate resp status.
   Response:
   pt appears uncomf with distended abd.
   Plan:
   possible paracentesis
